metadata.title: Efficient codes for memory determine pitch representations

abstract.text: Perceptual systems have finite memory resources and must store incoming signals in compressed formats. To test whether representations of a sound's pitch might derive from this need for compression, we compared discrimination of harmonic and inharmonic sounds across delays. In contrast to inharmonic spectra, harmonic spectra can be summarized, and thus compressed, using their fundamental frequency (f0). Despite being comparable for sounds presented back-to-back, discrimination was better for harmonic than inharmonic stimuli when sounds were separated in time, implicating memory representations unique to harmonic sounds.

Patterns of individual differences indicated that listeners use different representations depending on the time delay between sounds, directly comparing the spectra of temporally adjacent sounds, but transitioning to comparing f0s across delays. The need to compress sound into memory appears to determine reliance on f0-based pitch, and may explain its importance in music, in which listeners must extract relationships between notes separated in time.

body_text.text: Our sensory systems transduce information at high bandwidths, but have limited resources to hold this information in memory. In vision, short-term memory is believed to store schematic structure extracted from image intensities, e.g. object shape, or gist, that might be represented with fewer bits than the detailed patterns of intensity represented on the retina (1) (2) (3) (4) . For instance, at brief delays visual discrimination shows signs of being based on image intensities, believed to be represented in high-capacity but short-lasting sensory representations (5) . By contrast, at longer delays more abstract (6, 7) or categorical (8) representations are implicated as the basis of short-term memory.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: In other sensory modalities the situation is less clear. Audition, for instance, is argued to also make use of both a sensory trace and a short-term memory store (9) , but the representational characteristics of the memory store are not well characterized. There is evidence that memory for speech includes abstracted representations of phonetic features (10, 11) or categorical representations of phonemes themselves (12) (13) (14) . Beyond speech, the differences between transient and persistent representations of sound remain unclear. This situation plausibly reflects a historical tendency within hearing research to favor simple stimuli, such as single frequencies, for which there is not much to abstract or compress. Such stimuli have been used to characterize the decay characteristics of auditory memory (15) (16) (17) (18) , its vulnerability to interference (19, 20) , and the possibility of distinct memory resources for different sound attributes (21, 22) , but otherwise place few constraints on the underlying representations.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Here we explore whether auditory perceptual representations could be explained in part by memory capacity limitations. One widely proposed auditory representation is that of pitch (23, 24) .
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Pitch is the property which enables sounds to be ordered from low to high (25) , and is a salient perceptual characteristic of voices, musical instrument notes, and some environmental sounds.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Such sounds often contain frequencies that are harmonics -integer multiples of a single fundamental frequency (f0). Pitch is classically thought to be the perceptual correlate of this f0.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Despite the prevalence of this idea in textbook accounts of pitch, there is surprisingly little direct evidence that listeners utilize representations of a sound's f0 when making judgments about pitch.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: For instance, discrimination of two harmonic sounds is normally envisioned to involve a comparison of estimates of the sounds' f0s (23, 26) . But if the frequencies of the sounds are altered to make them inharmonic (lacking a single f0), discrimination remains accurate (26) (27) (28) (29) , even though there are no f0s to be compared. This result is what would be expected if listeners were using the spectrum rather than the f0, e.g. by tracking shifts in harmonics between sounds (30) . Although harmonic advantages are evident in some other tasks plausibly related to pitch perception (such as recognizing familiar melodies, or detecting out-of-key notes (29) ), the cause of this task dependence remains unclear.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: In this paper we consider whether these characteristics of pitch perception could be explained by memory constraints. One reason to estimate a sound's f0 might be that it provides an efficient summary of the spectrum: a harmonic sound contains many frequencies, but their values can all be predicted as integer multiples of the f0. This summary might not be needed if two sounds are presented back-to-back, as high-fidelity (but quickly-fading) sensory traces of the sounds could be compared. But it might become useful in situations where listeners are more dependent on a longer-lasting memory representation.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: We explored this issue by measuring effects of time delay on discrimination. Our hypothesis was that time delays would cause discrimination to be based on auditory memory representations (16, 31) . We tested pitch discrimination with harmonic and inharmonic stimuli, varying the length of silent pauses between sounds being compared. We predicted that if listeners summarize harmonic sounds with a representation of their f0, then performance should be better for harmonic compared to inharmonic stimuli. This prediction held across a variety of different types of sounds and task conditions, but only when sounds were separated in time. In addition, individual differences in performance across conditions indicate that listeners switch from representing the spectrum to representing the f0 depending on memory demands. Reliance on f0-based pitch thus appears to be driven in part by the need to compress sound into memory.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: We began by measuring pitch discrimination with and without an intervening delay between notes ( Figure 1a ), using recordings of real instruments that were resynthesized to be either harmonic or inharmonic (Figure 1b) . We used real instrument sounds to maximize ecological relevance.
body_text.section: Experiment 1: Discriminating instrument notes with intervening silence

body_text.text: Here and in subsequent experiments, sounds were made inharmonic by adding a random frequency 'jitter' to each successive harmonic; each harmonic could be jittered in frequency by up to 50% of the original f0 of the tone. Making sounds inharmonic renders them inconsistent with any f0, such that the frequencies cannot be summarized by a single f0. The same pattern of random 'jitter' was added to each of the two notes in a trial. There was thus a direct correspondence between the frequencies of the first and second note even though the inharmonic stimuli lacked an f0.
body_text.section: Experiment 1: Discriminating instrument notes with intervening silence

body_text.text: Participants heard two notes played by the same instrument (randomly selected on each trial from the set of cello, baritone saxophone, ukulele, pipe organ, and oboe, with the instruments each appearing an equal number of times within a given condition). The two notes were separated by 0, 5, or 10 seconds of silence. Notes always differed by either a quarter of a semitone (~1.5% difference between the note f0s) or a half semitone (~3% difference between the note f0s).
body_text.section: Experiment 1: Discriminating instrument notes with intervening silence

body_text.text: Participants judged whether the second note was higher or lower than the first.
body_text.section: Experiment 1: Discriminating instrument notes with intervening silence

body_text.text: We found modest decreases in performance for harmonic stimuli as the delay period increased (significant main effect of delay for both .25 semitone (F(2,22)=25.19, p<.001, hp 2 =.70, Figure 2c ), and .5 semitone conditions (F(2,22)=5.31, p<.05, hp 2 =.33). This decrease in performance is consistent with previous studies examining memory for complex tones (20, 32) . However, we observed a more pronounced decrease in performance for inharmonic stimuli, with worse performance compared to harmonic stimuli at both delays (5 seconds: t(11)=4.48, p<.001 for .25 semitone trials, t(11)=2.12, p=.057 for .5 semitone trials; 10 seconds: t(11)=3.64, p<.01 for .25 semitone trials, t(11)=4.07, p<.01 for .5 semitone trials) despite indistinguishable performance for harmonic and inharmonic sounds without a delay (t(11)=0.43, p=.67 for .25 semitone trials, t(11)=-0.77, p=.46 for .5 semitone trials). These differences produced a significant interaction between the effect of delay and that of harmonicity (F(2, 22)=7.66, p<.01, hp 2 =.41 for .25 semitone trials, F(2, 22)=3.77, p<.05, hp 2 =.26 for .5 semitone trials). This effect was present in both musicians and non-musicians (Supplementary Figure 1 ; averaging across the two difficulty conditions we found no main effect of musicianship: F(1,10)=3.73, p=.08, hp 2 =.27 , and no interaction between musicianship, harmonicity and delay length F(2,20)=0.58, p=.57, hp 2 =.06), suggesting that the harmonic advantage is not dependent on extensive musical training. Overall, the results of Experiment 1 are consistent with the idea that a sound's spectrum can mediate pitch discrimination over short time intervals (potentially via a sensory trace of the spectrum), but that the memory of a sound's pitch over longer periods relies on a representation of f0.
body_text.section: Experiment 1: Discriminating instrument notes with intervening silence

body_text.text: We replicated and extended the results of Experiment 1 using synthetic tones, the acoustic features of which can be more precisely manipulated. We generated complex tones that were either Harmonic or Inharmonic, applying fixed bandpass filters to all tones in order to remove coarse spectral cues that could otherwise be used to detect pitch changes ( Figure 2a ). The first audible harmonic of these tones was generally the 4 th harmonic (though could be the 3 rd or 5 th , depending on the f0 or jitter pattern). To gauge the robustness of the effect across difficulty levels, we again used two different f0 differences (.25 and .5 semitones).
body_text.section: Experiment 2: Discriminating synthetic tones with intervening silence

body_text.text: To further probe the effect of delay on representations of f0, we included a third condition ('Interleaved Harmonic') where each of the two tones on a trial contained half of the harmonic series ( Figure 2a ). One tone always contained harmonics [1, 4, 5, 8, 9, etc.] , and the other always contained harmonics [2, 3, 6, 7, 10, etc.] (26) . The order of the two sets of harmonics was randomized across trials. This selection of harmonics isolates f0-based pitch by eliminating common harmonics between the tones to be compared. While in the Harmonic and Inharmonic conditions listeners could use the correspondence of the individual harmonics to perform a pitch a. Schematic of trial structure for Experiment 1. During each trial, participants heard two notes played by the same instrument and judged whether the second note was higher or lower than the first note. Notes were separated by a delay of 0, 5, or 10 seconds. b. Power spectra of example harmonic and inharmonic (with frequencies jittered) notes from a cello. c. Results of Experiment 1 plotted separately for the two difficulty levels that were used. Error bars plot standard error of the mean.
body_text.section: Experiment 2: Discriminating synthetic tones with intervening silence

body_text.text: comparison, in the Interleaved Harmonic condition there is no direct correspondence between harmonics present in the first and second notes, such that the task can only be performed by estimating and comparing the f0s of the tones. By applying the same bandpass filter to each Interleaved Harmonic tone we sought to minimize timbral differences that are known to impair f0 discrimination (33) . Masking noise was included in all conditions to prevent distortion products from being audible, which might otherwise be used to perform the task. Performance without a delay was worse for Interleaved Harmonic tones than for the regular Harmonic and Inharmonic tones, but unlike those other two conditions, Interleaved Harmonic performance did not deteriorate significantly over time (Figure 2b ). There was no main effect of delay for either .25 semitones (F(2,48)=1.23, p=.30, hp 2 =.05) or .5 semitones (F(2,48)=2.56, p=.09, hp 2 =.10), in contrast to the significant main effects of delay for Harmonic and Inharmonic conditions at both difficulty levels (p<.001 in all cases). This pattern of results is consistent with the idea that there are two representations that listeners could use to discriminate pitch: a sensory trace of the spectrum which decays quickly over time, and a representation of the f0 which is better retained over a delay. The spectrum can be used in the Harmonic and Inharmonic conditions, but not in the Interleaved Harmonic condition.
body_text.section: Experiment 2: Discriminating synthetic tones with intervening silence

body_text.text: As in Experiment 1, the effects were qualitatively similar for musicians and non-musicians (Supplementary Figure 2) . Although there was a significant main effect of musicianship a. Schematic of stimuli and trial structure in Experiment 2. Left: During each trial, participants heard two tones and judged whether the second was higher or lower than the first. Tones were separated by a delay of 0, 5, or 10 seconds. Right: Power spectra of example notes from Harmonic, Inharmonic, and Interleaved Harmonic conditions. d. Results of Experiment 2, plotted separately for the two difficulty levels that were used. Error bars plot standard error of the mean.
body_text.section: Experiment 2: Discriminating synthetic tones with intervening silence

body_text.text: The purpose of Experiment 3 was to examine the effects of the specific inharmonicity manipulation used in Experiments 1 and 2. In Experiments 1 and 2, we used a different inharmonic jitter pattern for each trial. In principle, listeners might be able to learn a spectral pattern if it repeats across trials (36, 37) , such that the harmonic advantage found in Experiments 1 and 2 might not have been due to harmonicity per se, but rather to the fact that the harmonic pattern occurred repeatedly whereas the inharmonic pattern did not. In Experiment 3 we compared performance in a condition where the jitter pattern was held constant across trials ('Inharmonic-Fixed') vs. when it was altered every trial (though the same on the two notes of a trial) as in the previous experiments ('Inharmonic').
body_text.section: Experiment 3: Discriminating synthetic tones with a consistent inharmonic spectrum

body_text.text: Unlike the first two experiments we used adaptive procedures to measure discrimination thresholds. The transition to adaptive threshold measurements avoided difficulties associated with choosing pitch differences appropriate for the anticipated range of performance across the conditions. Participants completed 3-down-1-up two-alternative-forced-choice ('is the second tone higher or lower than the first') adaptive threshold measurements. Tones were either separated by no delay, a 1-second delay, or a 3-second delay (Figure 3a ). There were three different stimulus conditions: Harmonic tones (as in Experiment 2), Inharmonic tones where the jitter changed for every trial (as in Experiment 2), and Inharmonic-Fixed tones where the jitter pattern was fixed across a block of adaptive runs. Participants completed four adaptive runs for each delay and stimulus pair. Harmonic, Inharmonic and Inharmonic-Fixed conditions were each blocked; the delay conditions were intermixed within a block, resulting in 12 adaptive runs per block ( Figure 3b) , with approximately 60 trials per run on average. The order of these three blocks was randomized across participants. This design does not preclude the possibility that participants might learn a repeating inharmonic pattern given even more exposure to it, but it puts the inharmonic and harmonic tones on equal footing, testing whether the harmonic advantage might be due to relatively short-term learning of the consistent spectral pattern provided by harmonic tones.
body_text.section: Experiment 3: Discriminating synthetic tones with a consistent inharmonic spectrum

body_text.text: As shown in Figure 3c There was not a significant effect of the type of inharmonicity (F(1,22)=.07, p=.78, hp 2 =.003, comparing Inharmonic vs. Inharmonic-Fixed conditions), providing no evidence that participants learn to use specific jitter patterns over the course of a typical experiment duration. The harmonic advantage cannot be explained by the consistency of the harmonic spectral pattern across trials, as making the inharmonic spectral pattern consistent did not reduce the effect. Given this result, in subsequent experiments we opted to use 'Inharmonic' rather than 'Inharmonic-Fixed' stimuli, to avoid the possibility that the results might otherwise be biased by the choice of a particular jitter pattern. a. Schematic of trial structure for Experiment 3. Task was identical to that of Experiments 1 and 2, but with delay durations of 0, 1 and 3 seconds, and adaptive threshold measurements rather than method of constant stimuli. b. Example block order for Experiment 3, in which the 12 adaptive runs for each condition were presented within a contiguous block. The beginning of an example run is shown schematically for each type of condition. Stimulus conditions (Harmonic, Inharmonic, Inharmonic-Fixed) were blocked. Note the difference between the Inharmonic-Fixed condition, in which the same jitter pattern is used across all trials within a block, and the Inharmonic condition, in which the jitter pattern is different on every trial. Delay conditions were intermixed within each block. c. Results of Experiment 3.
body_text.section: Experiment 3: Discriminating synthetic tones with a consistent inharmonic spectrum

body_text.text: Error bars plot within-subject standard error of the mean.
body_text.section: Experiment 4: Discriminating synthetic tones with a longer inter-trial interval

body_text.text: To assess whether the inharmonic deficit could somehow reflect interference from successive trials (38) rather than the decay of memory during the inter-stimulus delay, we replicated Experiment 3 with a longer inter-trial interval. We included only the Harmonic and Inharmonic conditions, with and without a 3 second delay between notes. For each condition participants completed four adaptive threshold measurements without any enforced delay between trials, and four adaptive thresholds where we imposed a 4 second inter-trial interval (such that the delay between trials would always be at least 1 second longer than the delay between notes of the same trial). This experiment was run online because the lab was temporarily closed due to the COVID-19 virus.
body_text.section: Experiment 4: Discriminating synthetic tones with a longer inter-trial interval

body_text.text: The results were similar irrespective of the inter-trial interval. We found no significant interaction between inter-trial interval, within-trial delay, and Harmonic vs. Inharmonic stimuli (F(1,25)=0.05, p=.82, hp 2 =.002, Supplementary Figure 4 ). This result suggests that the inharmonic deficit is due to difficulties retaining the tones during the delay period, rather than some sort of interference from preceding stimuli.
body_text.section: Experiment 4: Discriminating synthetic tones with a longer inter-trial interval

body_text.text: Experiments 1-4 leave open the possibility that listeners might use active rehearsal of the stimuli (singing to themselves) to perform the task over delays. Although prior results suggest that active rehearsal does not obviously aid pitch discrimination over delays (16, 39) , it could in principle explain the harmonic advantage on the assumption that it is more difficult to rehearse an inharmonic stimulus, and so it seemed important to address. To assess whether the harmonic advantage reflects rehearsal, we ran two "one-shot" online experiments with much longer delay times, during which participants filled out a demographic survey. We assumed this unrelated task would prevent them from actively rehearsing the heard tone. These experiments were run online to recruit the large number of participants needed to obtain sufficient power. We have previously found that online participants can perform about as well as in-lab participants (37, 40) provided basic steps are taken to help ensure reasonable sound presentation (41) .
body_text.section: Experiments 5.1 and 5.2: One-shot discrimination with a longer intervening delay

body_text.text: Each participant completed only two trials in the main experiment. One trial had no delay between notes, as in the 0s delay conditions of the previous experiments. During the other trial participants heard one tone, then were redirected to a short demographic survey, and then heard the second tone ( Figure 4a ). The order of the two trials was randomized across participants. For each participant, both trials contained the same type of tones, randomly assigned. For Experiment 5.1, the tones were either Harmonic, Inharmonic, or Interleaved Harmonic (each identical to the tones used in Experiment 2). The two tones always differed in f0 by a semitone. The discrimination task was described to participants at the start of the experiment, such that participants knew they should try to remember the first tone before the survey and that they would be asked to compare it to a second tone heard after the survey. After participants had finished both trials of the experiment, they completed an additional short task originally intended to screen for poorly performing participants. In this task, participants completed 40 up/down discrimination trials -Harmonic and Inharmonic tones separated by 1 semitone in pitch and no delay in time.
body_text.section: Experiments 5.1 and 5.2: One-shot discrimination with a longer intervening delay

body_text.text: For both experiments we ran a large number of participants to obtain sufficient power given the small number of trials per participant. Participants completed the survey at their own pace. We One surprising aspect of these results is that performance for harmonic tones was no worse with the (long) delay between tones. We suspect this is related to the relatively low overall performance -pitch discrimination with a one-semitone difference is normally easy for typical human listeners.
body_text.section: Experiments 5.1 and 5.2: One-shot discrimination with a longer intervening delay

body_text.text: To get insight into this issue, we analyzed the additional task completed after the two main experimental trials. This additional task was identical to that of the no-delay trial of the main experiment, but with 40 trials (half with Harmonic and half with Inharmonic tones). Performance was 83.9% correct on average (Supplementary Figure 5a ) -substantially higher than the average performance on the single no-delay trial with Harmonic and Inharmonic stimuli (71.5%). This difference suggests that the absence of practice trials (intended to avoid putting the delay and nodelay conditions on unequal footing) reduced performance on the two test trials, potentially particularly limiting performance without a delay. Regardless of the explanation, this issue cannot account for the critical interaction between delay and harmonicity that we observed here as in the previous experiments. 14 Experiment 6: Individual differences in pitch discrimination
body_text.section: Experiments 5.1 and 5.2: One-shot discrimination with a longer intervening delay

body_text.text: The similarity in performance between harmonic and inharmonic tones without a delay provides circumstantial evidence that listeners are computing pitch changes in the same way for both types of stimuli, presumably using a representation of the spectrum in both cases. However, the results leave open the alternative possibility that listeners use a representation of the f0 for the harmonic tones despite having access to a representation of the spectrum (which they must use with the inharmonic tones), with the two strategies happening to support similar accuracy.
body_text.section: Experiments 5.1 and 5.2: One-shot discrimination with a longer intervening delay

body_text.text: To address these possibilities, and to explore whether listeners use different pitch encoding strategies depending on memory constraints, we employed an individual differences approach (43, 44) . The underlying logic is that performance on tasks that rely on the same perceptual representations should correlate across participants. Thus, if two discrimination tasks rely on similar representations, a participant with a low threshold on one task should tend to have a low threshold on the other task.
body_text.section: Experiments 5.1 and 5.2: One-shot discrimination with a longer intervening delay

body_text.text: In Experiment 6, we estimated participants' pitch discrimination thresholds either with or without a 3-second delay between stimuli, using a 3-down-1-up adaptive procedure (Figure 5a ).
body_text.section: Experiments 5.1 and 5.2: One-shot discrimination with a longer intervening delay

body_text.text: Stimuli included Harmonic, Inharmonic, and Interleaved Harmonic complex tones, generated as in Experiments 2-5. We used Inharmonic stimuli for which a different pattern of jitter was chosen for each trial (as opposed to the Inharmonic-Fixed stimuli from Experiment 3, where one pattern was used for all trials), because Experiment 3 showed similar results whether the inharmonic pattern was consistent or not, and because it seemed better to avoid a consistent jitter.
body_text.section: Experiments 5.1 and 5.2: One-shot discrimination with a longer intervening delay

body_text.text: Specifically, it seemed possible that fixing the jitter pattern across trials for each participant might create artifactual individual differences given that some jitter patterns are by chance closer to harmonic than others. Having the jitter pattern change from trial to trial produces a similar distribution of stimuli across participants and averages out the effect of idiosyncratic jitter patterns.
body_text.section: Experiments 5.1 and 5.2: One-shot discrimination with a longer intervening delay

body_text.text: We also tested Pure tones, and a fifth condition where each note contained two randomly chosen harmonics from each successive set of four (1 to 4, 5 to 8, etc.). By chance, some harmonics could be found in both notes. This condition (Random Harmonic) was intended as an internal a. Schematic of the two trial types in Experiment 5. Task was identical to that of Experiment 2, however for the 'delay' condition participants were redirected to a short demographic survey that they could complete at their own pace. b. Results of Experiment 5.1 (which had the same stimulus conditions as Experiment 2). Error bars plot standard error of the mean, calculated via bootstrap.
body_text.section: Experiments 5.1 and 5.2: One-shot discrimination with a longer intervening delay

body_text.text: replication of the anticipated results with Interleaved Harmonics.
body_text.section: Experiments 5.1 and 5.2: One-shot discrimination with a longer intervening delay

body_text.text: The main hypothesis we sought to test was that listeners use different representations of sound with and without a delay. The key predictions of this hypothesis are that listeners should use 1) the same representation for Harmonic and Inharmonic discrimination without a delay (indicated by high correlations between these two conditions), 2) different representations for Harmonic and Inharmonic discrimination with a delay (lower correlation), 3) different representations for Interleaved Harmonic discrimination compared to the other two conditions with no delay (because it requires a representation of the f0), but 4) similar representations for Interleaved Harmonic and Harmonic discrimination over a delay.
body_text.section: Experiments 5.1 and 5.2: One-shot discrimination with a longer intervening delay

body_text.text: We ran this study online to recruit sufficient numbers to measure the correlations of interest. This experiment was relatively long and difficult (it took approximately 2 hours to complete), and based on pilot experiments we anticipated that many online participants would perform poorly relative to in-lab participants. To obtain a criterion level of performance with which to determine inclusion for online participants, we ran 10 participants in the lab to establish acceptable performance levels. We calculated the overall mean threshold from the best three of four runs from the in-lab data for all conditions without a delay (five conditions), and excluded online participants whose mean threshold on the first run of those same 5 conditions (without a delay) were above this mean in-lab performance level. To avoid non-independence, we analyzed
body_text.section: Experiments 5.1 and 5.2: One-shot discrimination with a longer intervening delay

body_text.text: As shown in Figure 5c , thresholds were correlated to some extent for all pairs of conditions, presumably reflecting general factors such as attention or motivation that produce variation in performance across participants. However, some correlations were higher than others. Figure 5d plots the correlations for which our hypothesis makes critical predictions.
body_text.section: Individual Differences -Harmonic, Inharmonic and Interleaved Harmonic conditions

body_text.text: Correlations here and elsewhere were corrected for the reliability of the threshold measurements (45) , and thus could in principle be as high as 1 in the limit of large data. Because the threshold reliabilities were calculated from noisy threshold estimates, the corrected correlations could in practice slightly exceed 1.
body_text.section: Individual Differences -Harmonic, Inharmonic and Interleaved Harmonic conditions

body_text.text: Across participants, performance on Harmonic and Inharmonic conditions was highly correlated without a delay (rho=.89, p<.001). However, the correlation between Harmonic and Inharmonic conditions decreased with a delay (r=.71, p<.001, significant difference between correlations with and without a delay, p<.05, calculated via bootstrap). We observed the opposite pattern for the Harmonic and the Interleaved Harmonic conditions: the correlation was lower without a delay (r=.70, p<.001), and increased with a delay (r=.90, p<.001, significant difference between correlations, p<.05). This pattern of results yielded a significant interaction between the conditions being compared and the effect of delay (difference of differences between correlations with and without a delay = 0.38, p<.01). Overall, the results of the individual differences analysis indicate that when listening to normal harmonic tones, participants switch between two different pitch mechanisms depending on whether they are reliant on memory.
body_text.section: Individual Differences -Harmonic, Inharmonic and Interleaved Harmonic conditions

body_text.text: The results for Pure Tones were similar to those for the Harmonic condition (Figure 5e The Random Harmonic results largely replicated the findings from the Interleaved Harmonic condition (Figure 5c ). Evidently the changes that we introduced in the harmonic composition of the tones being compared in this condition were sufficient to preclude the use of the spectrum, and, as in the Interleaved Harmonic condition, performance was determined by f0based pitch regardless of the delay between notes.
body_text.section: Results with Pure Tones and Random Harmonic Condition

body_text.text: We examined the relationship between pitch perception and memory by measuring pitch discrimination with and without a time delay between stimuli. Across several experiments, we found that discrimination across a delay was better for harmonic sounds than for inharmonic sounds, despite being comparably accurate without a delay. This effect was observed over delays of a few seconds and persisted over longer delays with an intervening distractor task. We also analyzed individual differences in pitch discrimination thresholds across a large number of participants. This analysis showed that harmonic and inharmonic discrimination thresholds were highly correlated without a delay between sounds, but were less so with a delay. By contrast, thresholds for harmonic tones and tones designed to isolate f0-based discrimination showed the opposite pattern, becoming more correlated with a delay between sounds. Together, the results suggest that listeners use different representations depending on memory demands, comparing spectra for sounds nearby in time, and the f0 for sounds separated in time. The results provide evidence for multiple pitch mechanisms, reveal the constraints that determine when they are used, and demonstrate a form of abstraction within the auditory system whereby the representations of memory differ in format from those used for rapid on-line judgments about sounds.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Although the harmonic series imposes mathematical regularity on sound frequencies that is preserved to some extent by the peripheral auditory system (46) , it is unclear whether this regularity is essential to the memory benefit we describe here. Harmonic sounds may be more easily remembered simply because they are prevalent in the environment, such that humans have acquired representational transforms to efficiently represent them (e.g. by projection onto harmonic templates) (47) . In an alternate world in which vocalizations or other musical sounds all had a particular inharmonic spectral pattern, we might develop efficient representations of their spectrum instead (48) , conferring a memory advantage even in the absence of harmonicity.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Why don't listeners base pitch judgments of harmonic sounds on their f0s when sounds are backto-back? One possibility is that representations of f0 are in some cases less accurate and produce poorer discrimination than those of the spectrum if memory is not involved. The results with interleaved harmonics (stimuli designed to isolate f0-based pitch) are consistent with this idea, as discrimination without a delay was worse for interleaved harmonics than for either harmonic or inharmonic tones that had similar spectral composition across notes (we note that this deficit could also reflect other stimulus differences, such as the potentially interfering effects of the changes in the spectrum from note to note). The fact that performance with interleaved harmonics was similar with and without modest delays suggests that representations of the f0 are initially available in parallel with representations of the spectrum, with task demands determining which is used in the service of behavior. As time passes the high-fidelity representation of the spectrum appears to degrade, and listeners switch to more exclusively using a representation of the f0.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: In hearing research, the word 'pitch' has traditionally referred to the perceptual correlate of the f0 (24) . Here we presented evidence that listeners rely on a representation of the spectrum in some cases where scientists have presumed them to use the f0. However, under normal conditions (where sounds are harmonic) the note-to-note changes in the spectrum convey changes in f0, and thus help listeners make judgments about the f0 even though the f0 is apparently not explicitly represented. Consistent with this idea, listeners readily describe what they hear in the Inharmonic conditions of our experiments as a pitch change, as though the consistent shift in the spectrum is interpreted as a change in the f0. We thus propose that these spectral judgments should be considered part of pitch perception, which we construe to be the set of computations that enable judgments about a sound's f0.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: The use of time delays to study memory for frequency and/or pitch has a long tradition (49, 50) .
body_text.section: Relation to previous studies of pitch and pitch memory

body_text.text: Our results here are broadly consistent with this previous work, but to our knowledge provide the first evidence for differences in how representations of the f0 and the spectrum are retained over time. A number of studies have examined memory for tones separated by various types of interfering stimuli, and collectively provide evidence that the f0 of a sound is retained in memory.
body_text.section: Relation to previous studies of pitch and pitch memory

body_text.text: For example, intervening sounds interfere most with discrimination if their f0s are similar to the tones being discriminated, irrespective of whether the intervening sounds are speech or synthetic tones (21) , and irrespective of the spectral content of the intervening notes or the two comparison tones (20) . Our results complement these findings by showing that memory for f0 has different characteristics from that for frequency content (spectra), in showing how these differences impact pitch discrimination, and in suggesting that memory for f0 should be viewed as a form of compression. We also show that introducing a delay between notes forces listeners to use the f0 rather than the spectrum, which may be useful in experimentally isolating f0-based pitch in future studies.
body_text.section: Relation to previous studies of pitch and pitch memory

body_text.text: F0-based pitch seems to be particularly important in music perception, evident in prior results documenting the effect of inharmonicity on music-related tasks. Melody recognition, "sour" note detection, and pitch interval discrimination are all worse for inharmonic compared to harmonic tones, in contrast to other tasks such as up/down discrimination which can be performed equally well for both types of tones (29) . Our results here provide a potential explanation for these effects.
body_text.section: Relevance of f0-based pitch to music

body_text.text: Music often requires notes to be compared across delays or intervening sounds, as when assessing a note's relation to the tonic (51) , and the present results suggest that this should necessitate f0-based pitch. Musical pitch perception may have come to rely on representations of f0 as a result, such that even in musical tasks that do not involve storage across a delay, such as musical interval discrimination, listeners use f0-based pitch rather than the spectrum (29) . It is possible that similar effects occur for other patterns that occur frequently in music, such as common chords.
body_text.section: Relevance of f0-based pitch to music

body_text.text: Given its evident role in music perception, it is natural to wonder whether f0-based pitch is honed by musical training. Western-trained musicians are known to have better pitch discrimination than Western non-musicians (52) (53) (54) . But previous studies examining effects of musicianship on pitch discrimination used either pure tone or harmonic tone stimuli, and thus do not differentiate between representations of the f0 vs. the spectrum. We found consistent overall pitch discrimination advantages for musicians compared to non-musicians ( Supplementary Figures 1-3 ), but found no evidence that this benefit was specific to f0 representations: musicianship did not interact with the effects of inharmonicity or inter-stimulus delay. It is possible that more extreme variation in musical experience might show f0-specific effects. For instance, indigenous cultures in the Amazon appear to differ from Westerners in basic aspects of pitch (55) and harmony perception (56, 57) , raising the possibility that they might also differ in the extent of reliance on f0-based pitch. It is also possible that musicianship effects might be more evident if memory were additionally taxed with intervening distractor tones.
body_text.section: Relevance of f0-based pitch to music

body_text.text: Perception is often posited to involve inferences of parameters that capture how a stimulus was generated (58) . Such parameters can also provide compressed representations of sensory signals. Efficient coding has been proposed as a way to estimate generative parameters (59, 60) , and aspects of auditory representations (61) and discrimination (62) can be explained as consequences of efficient coding. Our results further link efficient coding to audition via memory.
body_text.section: Abstraction in perception and memory

body_text.text: We provide an example of abstract and compressed auditory memory representations that are plausibly domain-general, and in doing so explain some otherwise puzzling results in pitch perception (chiefly, the fact that conventional pitch discrimination tasks often do not tap into f0based pitch).
body_text.section: Abstraction in perception and memory

body_text.text: Memory could be particularly important in audition given that sound unfolds over time, with the structures that matter in speech, music, and other domains often extending over many seconds.
body_text.section: Abstraction in perception and memory

body_text.text: Other examples of auditory representations that discard details in favor of more abstract structures include the pitch "contour" of melodies, that listeners retain in some conditions in favor of the exact pitch intervals between notes (63), or summary statistics of sound textures that average across temporal details (64) . These representations may reflect memory constraints involved in comparing two extended stimuli even without a pronounced inter-stimulus delay.
body_text.section: Abstraction in perception and memory

body_text.text: Our results leave open how the two representations implicated in pitch judgments are instantiated in the brain. Pitch-related brain responses measured in humans have generally not distinguished representations of the f0 from that of the spectrum (65) (66) (67) (68) (69) , in part because of the coarse nature of human neuroscience methods. Moreover, we know little about how pitch representations are stored over time in order to mediate discrimination across a delay. In non-human primates there 22 is evidence for representations of the spectrum of harmonic complex tones (70) as well as of their f0 (71) , though there is increasing evidence for heterogeneity in pitch across species (72) (73) (74) (75) (76) .
body_text.section: Future directions

body_text.text: Neurophysiological and behavioral experiments with delayed discrimination tasks in non-human animals could shed light on these issues.
body_text.section: Future directions

body_text.text: Our results also indicate that we unconsciously switch between representations depending on the conditions in which we must make pitch judgments (i.e., whether there is a delay between sounds). One possibility is that sensory systems can assess the reliability of their representations and base decisions on the representation that is most reliable for a given context. Evidence weighting according to reliability is a common strategy in perceptual decisions (77) , and our results raise the possibility that such frameworks could be applied to understand memory-driven
body_text.section: Future directions

body_text.text: Another open question concerns the role of f0-based encoding in speech and voice perception (78) . Previous results suggest that f0 partially underlies recognition of familiar voices (29) , potentially indicating another domain where f0-based compression aids memory. However, memory for speech, and for music, is not limited to the f0 (79) (80) (81) . Our results suggest that examining the effects of memory on tasks in these domains could help to understand the underlying perceptual representations.
body_text.section: Future directions

body_text.text: All experiments were approved by the Committee on the use of Humans as Experimental Subjects at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and were conducted with the informed consent of the participants.
body_text.section: Participants.

body_text.text: Musicianship: Across all experiments, musicians were defined as individuals with five or more years of self-reported musical training and/or active practice/performance. Non-musicians had four or fewer years of self-reported musical training and/or active practice/performance.
body_text.section: Participants.

body_text.text: In all experiments, a MacMini computer running Psychtoolbox for MATLAB (82) was used to play sound waveforms. Sounds were presented to participants at 70 dB over Sennheiser HD280 headphones (circumaural) in a soundproof booth (Industrial Acoustics). Participants logged their responses via keyboard press.
body_text.section: Audio Presentation: In-Lab.

body_text.text: We used the crowdsourcing platform provided by Amazon Mechanical Turk to run experiments that necessitated large numbers of participants (Experiments 5 and 6), or when in-person data collection was not possible due to the COVID-19 virus (Experiment 4). Each participant in these studies used a calibration sound to set a comfortable level, and then had to pass a "headphone check" experiment that helped ensure they were wearing headphones or earphones as instructed (41) before they could complete the full experiment. The experimental stimuli were set to 15.5 dB below the level of the calibration sound, to ensure that stimuli were never uncomfortably loud.
body_text.section: Audio Presentation: Online.

body_text.text: Participants logged their responses by clicking buttons on their computer monitors using their mouse.
body_text.section: Audio Presentation: Online.

body_text.text: Feedback (correct/incorrect) was given after each trial for all tasks except for the two test trials of Experiment 5.1-5.2.
body_text.section: Feedback.

body_text.text: Procedure: Participants heard two instrument notes per trial, separated by varying amounts of silence (0, 5, and 10 seconds) and judged whether the second note was higher or lower than the first note. Participants heard 30 trials per condition, and all conditions were intermixed. The first stimulus for a trial began one second after the response was entered for the previous trial, such that there was at least a 1-second gap between successive trials.
body_text.section: Experiment 1: Discriminating instrument notes with intervening silence

body_text.text: Stimuli: Instrument notes were derived from the RWC Instrument database, which contains recordings of chromatic scales played on different instruments (83). We used recordings of baritone saxophone, cello, ukulele, pipe organ and oboe, chosen to cover a wide range of timbres.
body_text.section: Experiment 1: Discriminating instrument notes with intervening silence

body_text.text: Instrument tones were manipulated using the STRAIGHT analysis and synthesis method (84) (85) (86) .
body_text.section: Experiment 1: Discriminating instrument notes with intervening silence

body_text.text: STRAIGHT is normally used to decompose speech into excitation and vocal tract filtering, but can also decompose a recording of an instrument into an excitation signal and a spectrotemporal filter.
body_text.section: Experiment 1: Discriminating instrument notes with intervening silence

body_text.text: If the voiced part of the excitation is modeled sinusoidally, one can alter the frequencies of individual harmonics, and then recombine them with the unaltered instrument body filtering to generate inharmonic notes. This manipulation (86) leaves the spectral shape of the instrument largely intact. Previous studies with speech suggest that intelligibility of inharmonic speech is comparable to that of harmonic speech (87) . The frequency jitters for inharmonic instruments were chosen in the same way as the jitters for the inharmonic synthetic tones used in Experiments 26 2-6 (described below). The same pattern of jitter was used for both notes in a trial. STRAIGHT was also used to pitch shift the instrument notes to create pairs of notes that differed in f0 by a specific amount. Audio was sampled at 16,000 Hz. All notes were 400 ms in duration and were windowed by 20 ms half-Hanning windows.
body_text.section: Experiment 1: Discriminating instrument notes with intervening silence

body_text.text: Each trial consisted of two notes. The second note differed from the first by .25 or .5 semitone.
body_text.section: Experiment 1: Discriminating instrument notes with intervening silence

body_text.text: To generate individual trials, the f0 of the first note of each trial was randomly selected from a uniform distribution over the notes in a Western classical chromatic scale between 196 and 392
body_text.section: Experiment 1: Discriminating instrument notes with intervening silence

body_text.text: Hz (G3 to G4). A recording of this note, from an instrument selected from the set of 5 that were used (baritone saxophone, cello, ukulele, pipe organ and oboe), was chosen as the source for the first note in the trial (instruments were counterbalanced across conditions). If the second note in the trial was higher, the note 1 semitone above was used to generate the second note (the note 1 semitone lower was used if the second note of the trial was lower). The two notes were analyzed and modified using the STRAIGHT analysis and synthesis method 39, 37, 38 ; the notes were pitch flattened to remove any vibrato, shifted to ensure that the pitch differences would be exactly the intended pitch difference apart, and resynthesized with harmonic or inharmonic excitation. Some instruments, such as the ukulele, have slightly inharmonic spectra. These slight inharmonicities were removed for the 'harmonic' conditions due to the resynthesis.
body_text.section: Experiment 1: Discriminating instrument notes with intervening silence

body_text.text: Experiments 2, 3, 4, 5.1, and 6 used the same types of tones. The stimuli for Experiment 5.2 are described below. Synthetic complex tones were generated with exponentially decaying temporal envelopes (decay constant of 4 s -1 ) to which onset and offset ramps were applied (20 ms half-Hanning window). The sampling rate was 16,000 Hz for Experiment 2, and 48,000 for all others.
body_text.section: Stimuli for Experiments 2-6.

body_text.text: Tones included all harmonics up to the Nyquist limit, in sine phase, and were always 400 ms in duration.
body_text.section: Stimuli for Experiments 2-6.

body_text.text: In order to make notes inharmonic, the frequency of each harmonic, excluding the fundamental, was perturbed (jittered) by an amount chosen randomly from a uniform distribution, U(-.5, .5). This jitter value was chosen to maximally perturb f0. Jitter values were multiplied by the f0 of the tone, and added to the frequency of the respective harmonic. For example, if the f0 was 200 Hz and a jitter value of -0.39 was selected for the second harmonic; its frequency would be set to 322 Hz.
body_text.section: Stimuli for Experiments 2-6.

body_text.text: To minimize salient differences in beating, jitter values were constrained (via rejection sampling) such that adjacent harmonics were always separated by at least 30 Hz. The same jitter pattern was applied to every note of the stimulus for a given trial, such that the spectral pattern shifted coherently up or down even in the absence of an f0. Except for the Inharmonic-Fixed condition of Experiment 3, where one random jitter pattern was used for entire blocks of the experiment, a new jitter pattern was chosen for each trial.
body_text.section: Stimuli for Experiments 2-6.

body_text.text: Each complex tone was band-pass filtered in the frequency domain with a Gaussian transfer function (in log frequency) centered at 2,500 Hz with a standard deviation of half an octave. This filter served to ensure that participants could not perform the tasks using changes in the spectral envelope, and also to minimize timbral differences between notes in the Interleaved Harmonic condition. The filter parameters were chosen to ensure that the f0 was attenuated (to eliminate variation in a spectral edge at the f0) while preserving audibility of resolved harmonics (harmonics below the 10 th , approximately).
body_text.section: Stimuli for Experiments 2-6.

body_text.text: To ensure that differences in performance for Harmonic and Inharmonic conditions could not be mediated by distortion products, we added masking noise to these bandpass filtered notes. We low pass filtered pink noise using a sigmoidal (logistic) transfer function in the frequency domain.
body_text.section: Stimuli for Experiments 2-6.

body_text.text: The sigmoid had an inflection point at the third harmonic of the highest of the two notes on a trial, and a maximum slope yielding 40 dB of gain or attenuation per octave. We scaled the noise so that the noise power in a gammatone filter centered at the f0 was 10dB lower than the mean power of the three harmonics of the highest note of the trial that were closest to the 2,500Hz peak (and thus had greatest magnitude) of the Gaussian spectral envelope (29) . This noise power is sufficient to mask distortion products at the f0 (88, 89) . This filtered and scaled pink noise was added to each note, and did not continue through the silence in 'delay' conditions.
body_text.section: Stimuli for Experiments 2-6.

body_text.text: Procedure: Procedure was identical to Experiment 1, except stimuli were synthetic tones.
body_text.section: Experiment 2: Discriminating synthetic tones with intervening silence

body_text.text: Stimuli: Each trial consisted of two notes, described above in Stimuli for Experiments 2-6. The second tone differed from the first by .25 or .5 semitones. The first note of each trial was randomly selected from a uniform distribution on a logarithmic scale spanning 200 to 400 Hz. Tones were either Harmonic, Inharmonic, or Interleaved Harmonic. Interleaved Harmonic notes were synthesized by removing harmonics [1,4, 5, 8, 9, etc.] in one note, and harmonics [2, 3, 6, 7, etc.] in the other note. They were otherwise identical to the Harmonic tones (identical bandpass filter in the frequency domain, as well as noise to mask a distortion product at the fundamental). This manipulation was intended to isolate f0-based pitch, as it removes the note-to-note spectral correspondence between harmonics.
body_text.section: Experiment 2: Discriminating synthetic tones with intervening silence

body_text.text: Procedure: Participants heard two notes per trial, separated by varying amounts of silence (0, 1 and 3 seconds) and were asked whether the second note was higher or lower than the first note.
body_text.section: Experiment 3: Discriminating synthetic tones with a consistent inharmonic spectrum

body_text.text: Unlike Experiments 1 and 2, which used the method of constant stimuli, participants completed 2-up-1-down adaptive threshold measurements for each condition. Each run was initialized at a 1-semitone pitch difference and ended after 10 reversals. For the first 4 reversals, the f0 changed by a factor of 2, and for subsequent reversals by a factor of sqrt (2) . Each adaptive run was initialized at an f0 difference of 1 semitone (approximately 6%), and the maximum f0 difference was limited to 16 semitones. The adaptive procedure proceeded if participants reached this 16 semitone limit; if they continued to get trials incorrect the pitch difference would not increase above the 16 semitone limit, and if they got two in a row right, the pitch difference would decrease from 16 semitones by a factor of 2 or sqrt(2), depending on how many reversals had already occurred.
body_text.section: Experiment 3: Discriminating synthetic tones with a consistent inharmonic spectrum

body_text.text: In practice participants who hit this limit repeatedly were removed before analysis due to our exclusion criteria. Thresholds were estimated by taking the average of the final 6 reversals. The first stimulus for a trial began one second after the response was entered for the previous trial, such that there was at least a 1-second gap between successive trials.
body_text.section: Experiment 3: Discriminating synthetic tones with a consistent inharmonic spectrum

body_text.text: Stimuli: Each trial consisted of two notes, described above in Stimuli for Experiments 2-6. The first note of each trial was randomly selected from a uniform distribution on a logarithmic scale spanning 200 to 400Hz. Tones were either Harmonic, Inharmonic, or Inharmonic-Fixed, separated into three blocks, the order of which was counterbalanced across participants.
body_text.section: Experiment 3: Discriminating synthetic tones with a consistent inharmonic spectrum

body_text.text: Participants completed 12 adaptive thresholds within each block (3 delay conditions x 4 runs per condition). For the Inharmonic-Fixed block, a random jitter pattern was chosen at the beginning of the block and used for every trial within the entire block.
body_text.section: Experiment 3: Discriminating synthetic tones with a consistent inharmonic spectrum

body_text.text: Procedure: The procedure for Experiment 4 was identical to Experiment 3, except that the experiment was run on Amazon Mechanical Turk, with different time intervals between trials.
body_text.section: Experiment 4: Discriminating synthetic tones with a longer inter-trial interval

body_text.text: Participants completed two sets of adaptive threshold measurements. In the first, trials were initiated by the participant, and could begin as soon as they entered the response for the previous trial and clicked a button to start the next trial. Four adaptive threshold measurements per condition were taken in this way (Harmonic and Inharmonic stimuli both with and without a 3second delay). In the second set, a mandatory 4-second pause inserted between each trial, which could be initiated by the participant once the pause had elapsed. Four threshold measurements for the same conditions were taken in this way. The two sets of measurements were randomly intermixed.
body_text.section: Experiment 4: Discriminating synthetic tones with a longer inter-trial interval

body_text.text: To perform adaptive procedures online, stimuli were pre-generated (instead of being generated in real-time as was done for the in-lab studies). For each condition and possible f0 difference, the stimuli were drawn randomly from a set of 20 pre-generated trials (varying in the f0 of the first note, and in the jitter pattern for the Inharmonic trials).
body_text.section: Experiment 4: Discriminating synthetic tones with a longer inter-trial interval

body_text.text: Stimuli: Stimuli were identical to the Harmonic and Inharmonic conditions in Experiment 3.
body_text.section: Experiment 4: Discriminating synthetic tones with a longer inter-trial interval

body_text.text: Procedure. Participants were recruited using the Amazon Mechanical Turk crowdsourcing platform. Each participant completed two types of trials. In the first type of trial, they heard two consecutive notes and were asked whether the second note was higher or lower than the first.
body_text.section: Experiment 5.1, 5.2: One-shot discrimination with longer intervening delay

body_text.text: Notes were always separated in pitch by a semitone. They were allowed to listen to the trial twice before responding. For the second type of trial, participants were allowed to hear one note twice, then were directed to a demographic survey. Before the presentation of the first note participants were told that they would be subsequently asked whether a note heard after the survey was higher or lower in pitch than the note heard before the survey. After the survey, participants were presented with the second note (they could again listen to the note twice), and were asked to respond. Each participant heard the same stimulus type (Harmonic, Inharmonic, etc.) for each of the two trials. The order of the trials (with and without the intervening survey) was randomized across participants. Participants initiated the second trial by clicking a button after they entered their response for the first trial. For the trials with the demographic survey, we collected time stamps of when participants heard the first and second note in order to calculate the delay between notes. After completing the two trials and the survey, participants completed 40 up/down discrimination trials without a delay, half with Harmonic and half with Inharmonic tones. The pitch 30 difference in all trials was 1 semitone. The purpose of this task was to estimate baseline performance for each participant. We originally planned to use this to exclude poorly performing participants, but ended up using it as a comparison for the two main experimental trials, as described in the Results section.
body_text.section: Experiment 5.1, 5.2: One-shot discrimination with longer intervening delay

body_text.text: Stimuli. Stimuli for Experiment 5.1 were identical to those used in Experiments 2-4 (Harmonic, Inharmonic and Interleaved Harmonic conditions). Stimuli for Experiment 5.2 were Shepard tone stimuli generated by adding sine waves separated by octaves, then passing the resulting complex tones through the same fixed filter used in 5.1 (described above in Stimuli for Experiments 2-6), and adding the same type of low pass masking noise (calculated as if all the harmonics were present). To make Shepard tones inharmonic, we jittered each frequency by up to half an octave up or down, with jitter values chosen from a uniform distribution on a logarithmic frequency scale.
body_text.section: Experiment 5.1, 5.2: One-shot discrimination with longer intervening delay

body_text.text: Procedure: Both in lab and on Mechanical Turk, participants completed 2-up-1-down adaptive threshold measurements. The instructions were to judge whether the second note was higher or lower than the first note. The adaptive procedure was identical to that used in the first set of threshold measurements of Experiment 4 (each trial could be initiated by the participant as soon as they had entered their response for the previous trial). For the in-lab participants, we used the best three runs from each condition to set the inclusion criteria for online studies. For online participants, the first run of each condition was used to determine inclusion, and the final three runs of each condition were used for analysis. The order of the adaptive runs was randomized for each participant. There were 4 runs for each of the 10 conditions, for a total of 40 adaptive runs, randomized in order for each participant. Participants received feedback after each trial.
body_text.section: Experiment 6: Individual differences in pitch discrimination

body_text.text: Stimuli: Participants in lab and online were tested on 5 different types of stimuli, presented either with no delay or a 3-second delay between tones (10 conditions). The five types of stimuli were as follows:
body_text.section: Experiment 6: Individual differences in pitch discrimination

body_text.text: (1) Harmonic, (2) Inharmonic, and (3) Interleaved Harmonic, all identical to the same conditions in Experiment 2. (4) Pure Tones: We used the 4 th harmonic of the f0 (f0*4) so that the stimuli would overlap in frequency with the complex tones used in other conditions, which were filtered so that first audible harmonic was generally the 3 rd or 4 th harmonic. Low pass masking noise was omitted from the Pure condition given that distortion products were not a concern. (5) Random Harmonic: For each note, two harmonics were randomly chosen from harmonics 1 to 4, 5 to 8, etc. By chance, some harmonics could be present in both notes. This manipulation was intended to be intermediate between the Harmonic and Interleaved Harmonic conditions. In all conditions, the f0 of the initial tone for each trial was chosen randomly from a from a uniform distribution on a logarithmic scale spanning 200-400 Hz.
body_text.section: Experiment 6: Individual differences in pitch discrimination

body_text.text: As in Experiment 4, stimuli were pre-generated to enable online threshold measurements. For each condition and possible f0 difference, the stimuli were drawn randomly from a set of 20 pregenerated trials (varying in the f0 of the first note, and in the jitter pattern for the inharmonic conditions).
body_text.section: Experiment 6: Individual differences in pitch discrimination

body_text.text: A power analysis of pilot data for Experiments 1 and 2 showed an effect size of d=1.25 for the difference between harmonic and inharmonic conditions at 5 seconds. We thus aimed to run at least 6 musicians and 6 non-musicians to be able to analyze the two groups separately and have an 80% chance of detecting the harmonic advantage at a p<.05 significance level (using paired t-tests). Power analyses for Experiments 1-4 and Experiment 6 (in lab baseline) used G*Power (90) . Experiment 2 was run in combination with other experiments (not described here) that were not as well powered and required more data, hence the additional participants. Experiment 6 (in-lab baseline): A pilot experiment for the in-lab portion of Experiment 6 showed an effect size of d= 1.32 for the difference for the best three runs of 17 pilot participants between Harmonic and Inharmonic thresholds with a delay. Thus, for the in-lab portion of Experiment 6 we aimed to run at least 6 participants in order to be 80% sure of seeing an effect this size at a p<.05 significance level (using a one-sided Wilcoxon signed-rank test).
body_text.section: Experiments 1 and 2:

body_text.text: Experiments 3-4 used the same basic method as Experiment 6, with the addition of a 1-second-delay condition and the Fixed-Jitter condition (Experiment 3) and inter-trial delays (Experiment 4). We used the same pilot data described above for Experiment 6 (in-lab baseline), but with the exclusion criteria to be used for Experiments 3-4, eliminating participants whose average threshold across the first run of each condition was greater than 3% (approximately half a semitone). This eliminated 6 of 17 pilot participants, and the resulting effect size for the Harmonic-Inharmonic difference at a 3-second delay was d=1. 49 . Based on the rough intuition that the effect of the Inharmonic-Fixed manipulation or the inter-trial delay might produce an effect approximately half this size, we sought to be 80% likely to detect an effect half as big as that observed in our pilot data, at a p<.05 significance (using a two-sided Wilcoxon signed-rank test). This yielded a target sample size of 17 participants. We did not plan to recruit equal numbers of musicians and non-musicians due to the similarity between groups in Experiments 1-2.
body_text.section: Experiments 3 and 4:

body_text.text: Experiment 5: Experiment 5 used stimuli similar to those of Experiment 2 (same tones but a larger pitch difference: 1 semitone in Experiment 5 compared to .25 and .5 semitones in Experiment 2), but had a one-shot design (each participant only had two trials, one without a delay and one with a delay). To approximate the number of participants needed we bootstrapped using data from Experiment 2, treating each trial as an independent participant and estimating data distributions using different numbers of sampled trials. For each possible sample size we computed the bootstrap distribution of the difference in performance between the Harmonic and Inharmonic conditions with a delay, as well as a null distribution obtained with conditions permuted across participants. We sought the sample size yielding an 80% chance of seeing a significant Harmonic-Inharmonic difference (i.e. where 95% of the bootstrap samples showed a difference exceeding the 97.5 th percentile of the null distribution), yielding a target sample size of 151 participants in each condition. We made no attempt to recruit equal numbers of musicians and non-musicians, as we did not plan to analyze those groups separately given the similar results across groups observed in the experiments we ran prior to this. Experiment 6, Online Participants: For the online portion of Experiment 6, we performed a power analysis by bootstrapping pilot data (an earlier version of Experiment 6 with slightly different stimuli). For each of a set of sample sizes we computed bootstrap distributions of the interaction term (difference of differences between the conditions being compared, Harmonic/Inharmonic and Interleaved-Harmonic), as well as null distributions obtained by permuting conditions across participants. We found that a sample size of 154 yielded a 90% chance of seeing the interaction present in our pilot data at a p<.05 significance level. We ran more than this number of participants to allow performance-based exclusion. As with Experiments 3-5, we made no attempt to recruit equal numbers of musicians and non-musicians.
body_text.section: Experiments 3 and 4:

body_text.text: For Experiments 1, 2 and 5 we calculated percent correct for each condition. For Experiments 1 and 2, data was evaluated as normal by eye and significance was calculated using paired t-tests and repeated-measures ANOVAs. We used mixed-model ANOVAs to examine the effects of musicianship (to compare within-and between-group effects).
body_text.section: Statistics.

body_text.text: For Experiment 5, the significance of the differences between conditions and the significance of interactions were calculated via bootstrap (10,000 samples). To calculate the significance of the interaction between conditions, we first calculated the interaction (the difference of differences in means with and without a delay). For instance, for the Harmonic and Inharmonic conditions this term is as follow: Then, we approximated a null distribution for this interaction, permuting conditions across participants and recalculating the difference of differences 10,000 times. To determine statistical significance we compared the actual value of the interaction to this null distribution.
body_text.section: Statistics.

body_text.text: Data distributions were non-normal (skewed) for threshold experiments (Experiments 3,4 and 6), so non-parametric tests were used for all comparisons. Wilcoxon signed-rank tests were used for pairwise comparisons between dependent samples (for example, two conditions for the same participant group). To compare performance across multiple conditions or across musicianship we used F statistics for repeated-measures ANOVAs (for within group effects) and mixed-model ANOVAs (to compare within and between group effects). However, because data were non-normal, we evaluated the significance of the F statistic with approximate permutation tests, randomizing the assignment of the data points across the conditions being tested 10,000 times, and comparing the F statistic to this distribution.
body_text.section: Statistics.

body_text.text: We used Spearman's rank correlations to examine individual differences in Experiment 6.
body_text.section: Statistics.

body_text.text: Correlations were corrected for the reliability of the threshold measurements using the Spearman correction for attenuation (45) . We used standardized Cronbach's alpha as a measure of reliability (91, 92) , calculating the reliability across the 3 analyzed adaptive track runs for each condition.
body_text.section: Statistics.

body_text.text: Standard errors for correlations were estimated by bootstrapping the correlations 10,000 times.
body_text.section: Statistics.

body_text.text: To calculate the significance of the interaction between conditions, we first calculated the interaction (the difference of differences). For instance, for the Harmonic and Inharmonic conditions, this term was: Then, we approximated a null distribution for this interaction, permuting conditions across participants and recalculating the difference of differences 10,000 times. To determine statistical significance we compared the actual value of the interaction to this null distribution.
body_text.section: Statistics.
