BIBREF91.title: Results of Experiment 5.2, replication of Experiment 5.1 with Harmonic and Inharmonic Shepard tones. Error bars plot standard error of the mean

FIGREF0.text: Experiment 1 -Harmonic advantage when discriminating instrument notes across a delay.

FIGREF1.text: Experiment 2 -Harmonic advantage when discriminating synthetic tones across a delay.

FIGREF2.text: , thresholds were matched for all conditions with no delay (no significant difference between any of the conditions (Z<1.61, p>.11 for all pairwise comparisons, Wilcoxon sign rank test, used because the distribution of thresholds was non-normal). However, thresholds were elevated (worse) for both the Inharmonic and Inharmonic-Fixed conditions with even a 1 second delay (Inharmonic: Z=2.86, p<.01; Inharmonic-Fixed: Z=2.19, p<.05), and were much worse in both conditions with a 3-second delay (Inharmonic: Z=3.98, p<.0001; Inharmonic-Fixed: Z=2.52, p<.05). We again observed no interaction between musicianship, stimulus type (Harmonic, Inharmonic, Inharmonic-Fixed), and delay length (F(4,84)=1.05, p=.39, hp 2 =.05, see Supplementary Figure 3).

FIGREF3.text: Experiment 3 -Harmonic advantage persists for consistent inharmonic jitter pattern.

FIGREF4.text: measured the time interval between the onset of the first note before the survey and the onset of the second note after the survey. Prior to analysis we removed participants who completed the survey in under 20 seconds (proceeding through the survey so rapidly as to suggest that the participant did not read the questions; 1 participant), or participants who took longer than 3 minutes (12 participants). Of the remaining 801 participants across both experiments, the mean time spent on the survey was 61.2 seconds (standard deviation of 25.9, median of 55.1 seconds and median absolute deviation of 19.0 seconds. There was no significant difference between the time taken for each of the conditions (Z<=1.13, p>=.10 for all pairwise comparisons). As shown in Figure 4b, Experiment 5.1 qualitatively replicated the results of Experiments 1 and 2 even with the longer delay period and concurrent demographic survey. Performance in the Inharmonic condition was worse with the delay than without a delay (p<.001, via bootstrap), whereas performance in the Harmonic and Interleaved Harmonic conditions was similar with and without a delay (Harmonic with vs. without delay: p=.30; Interleaved Harmonic with vs. without delay: p=.36). Moreover, performance in the Harmonic condition was better than that in the Inharmonic condition only with a delay (p<.001), producing an interaction between the type of tone and the delay (p=.02).

FIGREF5.text: Experiment 5.2 was identical to Experiment 5.1 except the stimuli were Harmonic and Inharmonic Shepard tones (42). These tones had only one frequency component per octave, rendered either in perfect octave relations (Harmonic) or with the component frequencies jittered (Inharmonic). In the latter case frequencies were each jittered by a random amount between half an octave up or down (uniformly distributed). This experiment was intended as a replication of Experiment 5.1 with somewhat different stimuli. We saw a similar effect as in Experiment 5.1 (Supplementary Figure 5b) -discrimination of harmonic tones was similar with and without the delay (p=.13), but performance for inharmonic tones was worse with the delay (p=.032).

FIGREF6.text: Experiment 5 -Harmonic advantage persists over longer delays with intervening task.

FIGREF7.text: only the three subsequent threshold measurements from online participants. This inclusion procedure selected 160 of 450 participants for the final analyses shown in Figure 5b-e. See Supplementary Figure 6 for in-lab results and Supplementary Figure 7 for results with a less stringent inclusion criteria (the main effects remain unchanged with this less stringent criteria). Mean Thresholds The pattern of mean threshold measurements obtained online qualitatively replicated the results of Experiments 1-5 (Figure 5b). Inharmonic thresholds were indistinguishable from Harmonic thresholds without a delay (Z=1.28, p=.20), but were higher when there was a delay between sounds (Z=-8.83, p<.0001). This produced a significant interaction between effects of tone type and delay (F(1,159)=80.84, p<.0001, hp 2 =.34). And as in the previous experiments, there was no significant effect of delay for the Interleaved Harmonic condition (Interleaved Harmonic condition with vs. without delay; Z=-0.06, p=.96).

FIGREF8.text: ), with quantitatively indistinguishable mean thresholds (without delay: Z=0.95, p=.34, with delay: Z=-0.85, p=.39). Moreover, the correlations between Harmonic and Pure Tone thresholds were high both without and with a delay, and not significantly different (p=.52). These results suggest that similar representations are used to discriminate pure and harmonic complex tones. In addition the correlations between the Pure Tone condition and the Inharmonic and Interleaved Harmonic conditions showed a similar pattern to that for the Harmonic condition, producing a significant interaction between the conditions being compared and the effect of delay (difference of differences between correlations with and without a delay = 0.32, p<.05).

FIGREF9.text: Experiment 6 -Individual differences suggest different pitch representations depending on memory demands. a. Schematic of the five types of stimuli used in Experiment 6. Task and procedure (adaptive threshold measurements) were identical to those of Experiment 4, but with no inter-trial delays. b. Discrimination thresholds for all stimulus conditions, with and without a 3-second delay between tones. Here and in panels d-e, error bars plot standard error of the mean, calculated via bootstrap. c. Matrix of the correlation between thresholds for all pairs of conditions. Correlations are Spearman's rho, corrected for the reliability of the threshold measurements (i.e., corrected for attenuation). Corrected correlations can slightly exceed 1 given that they are corrected with imperfect estimates of the reliabilities. d. Comparison between Harmonic/Inharmonic and Harmonic/Interleaved Harmonic threshold correlations, with and without a delay. e. Comparison between Pure Tone condition correlation with and without a delay.

FIGREF10.text: 16 participants were recruited for Experiment 1. 4 of these scored less than 60% correct across all conditions and their data was removed. The remaining participants (N=12, 5 female, mean age = 42.5 years, S.D. = 19 years) included 6 non-musicians and 6 musicians (24.5 years of training and active performance, S.D. = 16).

FIGREF11.text: were recruited for Experiment 2. 2 of these did not finish the experiment, and their data was not analyzed. Of the remaining 32 participants, 7 scored less than 60% correct across all conditions and were removed. The remaining participants (N=25, 12 female, mean age= 31.4 years, S.D.=14.7 years) included 10 non-musicians and 15 musicians (mean=16 years of musical training and active performance, S.D.=12.2 years).Experiment 3: 35 participants were recruited for Experiment 3. 3 of these did not complete the experiment or were removed for non-compliance. An additional 9 participants were removed from analysis because their average threshold across the first run of each condition was greater than 3% (approximately half a semitone). The remaining participants (N=23, 9 female, mean age=36.0 years, S.D.=16.6 years) included 11 non-musicians and 12 musicians (mean=17.1 years of musical training and active, S.D.=13.5) Experiment 4: 50 participants were recruited online for Experiment 4. 24 participants were removed from analysis because their average threshold across the first run of each condition was greater than 3% (approximately half a semitone). The remaining participants (N=26, 13 female, mean age=38.5 years, S.D.=13.1 years) included 15 non-musicians and 10 musicians (mean=8.9 years of musical training and active, S.D.=3.1). Experiment 5.1-5.2: Before analysis, we removed the participants who completed the demographic survey (the intervening task that all participants completed between presentations of the first and second notes in the 'delay' condition) in either less than 20 seconds, which we believed made it unlikely that those participants read and paid attention to all the questions, or greater than 3 minutes. 1 and 12 participants were excluded via these criteria, respectively. After these exclusions, 477 people completed experiment 5.1 (186 female, mean age = 36.7 years, S.D. = 12.2 years), and 324 people completed experiment 5.2 (137 female, mean age = 37.9 years, S.D. = 12.3 years). Of the total 801 participants, 383 reported some form of musical training, and 171 of those reported greater than four years of training (mean=13.7 years, S.D.=11.9 years). Experiment 6: 10 participants were recruited for the in-lab baseline for Experiment 6 (5 female, mean age=34.1, S.D.=13.8, 6 had over 4 years of musical training, mean=18.3 years, S.D.=7.8 years). 450 participants were recruited for the online component of Experiment 6. 290 were removed from analysis because their average threshold (across all 5 conditions) on the first run of the nodelay trials was greater than the in-lab average for those same conditions (2.47%). The remaining set of 160 participants (71 female, mean age=25.3 years, S.D.=9.1 years) included 110 who reported some form of musical training, and 72 participants who reported greater than four years of musical training (mean=10.9 years, S.D.=6.9 years).

TABREF0.text: As in Experiment 1, Harmonic and Inharmonic tones were similarly discriminable with no delay(Figure 2b; t(24)=-0.72, p=.48 for .5 semitone trials, t(24)=0.09, p=.93 for .25 semitone trials).Discrimination thresholds were comparable to previous measurements for stimuli with resolved harmonics(34,35). However, performance with Inharmonic tones was again significantly worse with a delay (5-second delay: t(24)=4.61 p<.001 for .25 semitones, t(24)=4.96, p<.0001 for .5 semitones; 10-second delay: t(24)=4.92, p<.0001 for .25 semitones, t(24)=6.11, p<.0001 for .5 semitones), yielding interactions between delay and harmonicity (F(2,48)=10.71, p<.001, hp 2 =.31 for .25 semitones, F(2,48)=26.17, p<.0001, hp 2 =.52 for .5 semitones).

TABREF1.text: (F(1,23)=10.28, p<.01, hp 2 =.99), there was no interaction between musicianship, stimulus type (Harmonic, Inharmonic, Interleaved Harmonic), and delay length (F(4,92)=0.19, p=.94, hp 2 =.01).
